intro: Rosa arvensis f. transalpina, commonly known as the Transalpine wild rose, is a horticultural form of the common dog玫瑰. It is a deciduous shrub characterized by its fragrant, pinkish-white flowers and thorny stems. The plant typically grows in open, sunny habitats such as meadows and disturbed soils. Its leaves are compound, with five to seven leaflets, and it produces rosehips that are reddish-orange when mature. This cultivar is valued for its ornamental qualities and adaptability to various garden conditions.
